answers.answer: The sunshine likely has nothing to do with this at all.  You have had a significant shift in your vision which could be related to a medication side effect, diabetes, eye strain, or simply presbyopia which is age related loss of near focus.  There are of course other possiblities but a good, thorough eye exam with an ophthalmologist would be the place to start.  I'm sure this mystery can be easily unraveled.  Good Luck.MJK MD

Dear arizonared,I would recommend that you seek the care of an eyeMD to determine the cause of your blurred vision.  There are a number of possible causes such as farsightedness and the exact cause needs to be determined in view of your injury.Dr. FeldmanSandy T. Feldman, M.D., M.S.ClearView Eye and Laser Medical CenterSan Diego, California

question: Hi,I am not sure if this is the correct forum in which to post my question/symptoms, but I will try anyway. In the last 2 days, I have suddenly gained blurred vision. If I look at things far away, I can see things fairly ok. But anything within a couple of feet suddenly become blurred and it is a real effort just to see.Prior to this, although I wore corrective lenses for a weak eye muscle, I have had really good vision.I am thinking that it could be connected to the fact that I was outside in the sun for about 6 hours on Saturday. I wore sunglasses, but I am wondering if they were not very good and I could have sustained some eye damage because of it.What do you think this could be?
title: Sudden Blurred vision - What could it be?
